text:
Frankly, those in power will virtually always slant the balance sheet in their favor. Which would be understandable if they were in personal financial stress. But when you've already amassed enough for about FIFTY lifetimes, why keep spinning the wheel? Why not boost your workers' wages so their stress level goes away (like yours you rich bastards)? 

These CHRONICALLY depressed areas need to develop some new industries that are sustainable, new, just, and fair . . . Not sure what these industries might be but somehow some value added products might be produced locally to inject life into these places. Doing the same thing repeatedly and somehow thinking things will change is illogical. To have change, changes must be made. Political promises come around every election and we line up like STUPID cows to slurp up the bullshit yet again. 

Waiting for someone "out there" to save you . . . you'll probably die waiting. Just do something to really help yourself. It might be as simple as planting a giant garden with others in your neighborhood. Vegetables, fruit trees, keep bees, chickens, etc. A garden can EASILY save you 5 or 6 THOUSAND per year. And quit being a mindless idiotic American consumer. Stop buying stuff. Stay home, play with your kids, clean your house, tend your new (!) garden. Go ahead and complain but damn it - do SOMETHING, do a LOT of little somethings to help yourself and your neighbors

text: Oh my God, Trump and his political allies have to rely on "sacrifice" and "patriotism" to win a trade war which Trump said was very easy to win? Americans better be prepared for more sacrifice and patriotism are needed in the way ahead when China is forced to expand its trade to other world markets to replace the US. US trade accounted for only 20% of the total trade of China. Cut it, and China will suffer for a while. But it can mend that hole within a year or two because Chinese companies are hardworking and they are willing to cut their profit margin to the bare minimum if it means survival. I was in Yi Wu Distribution Market at Honzhou and was stunned to learn that the exporter makes only $0.001 profit on each mobile phone decoration piece they ship. But they make it up by the bulk sale and the vendor is a millionaire, and a very hard working one. Beat China's work ethic if you can. But if you can't beat them, join them and both can prosper together. Ban China, the US only has to draw more and more sacrifice and patriotism until the American people find out how foolish Trump really is.

text:
@Richard Giardelli - Collusion or not, that's not what matters.  What is, in point of fact, a high crime, is Obstruction, a crime that Trump is constantly committing, and no one who is even remotely conscious of realty can deny that fact.  And, when it comes right down to it, Trump deserves his day in court; the only court that, at present, has jurisdiction, is Congress.  As soon as they announce that they are beginning an impeachment investigation, the entire judicial branch no longer has standing, except as an arm of congress.  And- impeachment is Not overthrowing an election.  In point of fact, impeachment is there to keep a President, or a Supreme Court Justice honest.  And, in Federal Government, the Only body that can remove anyone from office- is Congress.  It is their job, as mandated by the US Constitution, to provide the President with oversight- and if the President screws up, if he impedes investigations that are, at their core, intended to clear him of all charges and suspicions, then that is obstruction.  In the end, the only person responsible for the President's bad behavior- is Donald Trump.

As for the House blocking him- they are trying to get him to do his job, but the petty narcissistic twit can't even stay in the same room before storming out and then blaming Nancy Pelosi and company for his own poor behavior.  

As for Obama, Holder, Clinton, and company, well, they've got zero to do with any of this, except as victims of libel and slander on the part of the Trump Regime and its parade of crooked lawyers and propagandists.  Too bad they cannot, as yet, sue Trump and his agents for their civil offenses.  That, of course, will have to wait until he is out of office, whether that is this year, next, or when ever he finally relinquishes power (he has often said that we would not honor any election result that resulted in a loss for him).

And, as for a CNN coverup, sorry, but they don't do that sort of thing.  That's the sort of thing that right wing propaganda channels are always trying to do.

text:
I'm a farmer. I'm doing just fine. I didn't paint myself into a  corner by only exporting to foreign countries. That's ridiculous. I sell to American consumers because they also have to eat. No one is forcing this guy to just grow soy beans. Grow something else when soy fails you.  I grow wheat and alfalfa sold to dairy farmers and the USA market is very strong.  He's not a very wise farmer if he didn't have plan B & C should plan A fail. Its his own fault and CNN capitalized on that. I voted for Trump and that particular  Ohio farmer in no way represents my farming community. We are doing well. 
And...do not be fooled by the cries of global warming. In our area, we have plenty of water. Crops are flourishing, crops are  selling, my 401k doing better than the previous 8 years without question. I didn't apply for the free money either so I paid for my own repairs which keeps my farming community alive by supporting local businesses.

text:
And you are an example of what‚Äôs wrong with Americans: selfishness and navel gazing:
‚Ä¢ You‚Äôre doing just fine at your job so anyone who‚Äôs not doing well at the same occupation is just a whiny loser. 
‚Ä¢ After decades of extensive, multinational scientific research, credible climate scientists have determined that recurring, detrimental changes in climate is now the biggest threat to humanity‚Äôs future on the planet, but they are wrong‚Äîglobal warming is a hoax because the weather is not causing me any trouble. 
‚Ä¢ Because I like Trump, everything he does and says is right. He appoints the best people for his administration and they perform their jobs efficiently and with integrity. They can be trusted to act in the public‚Äôs best interest, just like Trump. It‚Äôs too bad he filled all of the appointments by lunchtime his first day. There‚Äôs a waitlist of people who want to work for him and the original appointments aren‚Äôt going anywhere‚Äîthey love their jobs and work so well with their staffs and colleagues; they aren‚Äôt going anywhere. At the mixer Trump organized, they all spontaneously pledged their loyalty to Trump, despite his vehement insistence that it wasn‚Äôt necessary and that their only duty was to the Constitution and the American people. The economy is doing well because of Trump. (The US economy stops the exact second the winner of the US Presidential election is announced. It then resets to ‚Äúnonexistent.‚Äù The stock exchange resets to zero and the deficit goes away. It all restarts the next second. So, Trump deserves the credit for the healthy economy. The fact that the data and charts show the economy is simply continuing the trend from the Obama Administration is just a coincidence. The economy reset and restarted, remember?

Okay, back to reality, Trump is a loser. He fails at epic proportions. The only thing he‚Äôs been successful at is being a fraud on every level of his life. He was given almost half a billion dollars and proceeded to start and fail one business after the other. He went into bankruptcy six times. SIX! He bankrupted a casino, for crying out loud! He would have made more money if he had put it in the bank to draw interest. In other words, the only way for him to improve anything is for him not to touch it. Everything he touches turns into a big, steaming pile of üí©. He was a loser before this abomination of an administration occurred and he‚Äôs continuing the trend. He‚Äôs in his seventies and has the temperament, discipline, maturity, impulse-control, vocabulary, and intelligence‚Äîboth emotional and mental‚Äîof a toddler. He is a malignant narcissist and a compulsive liar. He seems incapable of basic decency and integrity. 

I truly do not understand how any decent person could support Trump. There‚Äôs no excuse for it. His many, many deficiencies have been uncovered and reported. This isn‚Äôt about perfection, it‚Äôs about an expectation of basic, ethical behavior in an adult.The majority of people still supporting Trump are doing so because they are just like him. It‚Äôs appalling that so many Americans are so lacking in sense and morality but it‚Äôs a reality we have to deal with. The majority of them are blinded by some flavor of bigotry: For some, it‚Äôs racism against minorities. For others it‚Äôs sexism against women in power and in control of their own lives and bodies. For still others, it‚Äôs the xenophobia and arrogance of looking down on people from other countries. Of course, many have more than one affliction. 

There is another recurring phenomenon I‚Äôve noticed about many Trump supporters that may explain their baffling connection to him: their inability to understand anything other than the most simplistic facet of a situation. With some it‚Äôs a lack of factual information or the refusal to accept factual information but with others, it is honestly just plain stupidity. Yeah, that‚Äôs right; I said it. More importantly, I won‚Äôt apologize for saying it. Some of the stupidity can‚Äôt be helped, but there are some that refuse to put any effort into understanding and rationally addressing an issue. Some mistake their strong emotion for fact. I don‚Äôt care how passionately you feel about abortion or homosexuality or whatever bogeyman du jour the Republican Party is using to manipulate the general public. There are always going to be people doing or existing in ways that frighten or anger you. TOO BAD. They have the God given freedom to figure life out for themselves, just as you have. If you don‚Äôt like it, ignore it. Better yet, tend to your own business and let others do the same.

In reading the comments I see many ‚Äúyou voted for him and got what you deserve‚Äù comments. 
Americans had to vote for either Clinton or Trump in November 2016. That‚Äôs not the voters fault. There wasn‚Äôt even a ‚Äúlesser of two evils‚Äù option in that election.
Farmers are businessmen, and are therefore generally Republicans. 
Trumps strategy in the primaries made an unqualified con man the Republican candidate. The only Democrat who could lose to Donald Trump was Hillary Clinton, and that is not the farmers fault either. 
The DNC, who decided in 2009 Hillary Clinton would be the candidate in 2016 and told Democrats they would not be supported by the DNC if they ran against Hillary (Bernie Sanders was an Independent), is more responsible for the outcome of that election than the Republicans who voted for the Republican candidate. 
The ‚ÄúParty‚Äù selects ‚Äúcandidates‚Äù in Autocracies. The people select candidates in Democracies. Think about that for just a second...the Democratic Party didn‚Äôt support Democracy. 
And that‚Äôs not the farmers fault either.

text: Farmers are complaining, its understandable. But when there is an abundance of product on the market with no buyers because they don't need it, what do expect. in 2012 the US & Brazil each produced about 90 million metric ton of soybeans, Argentina 40mmt, Canada 5. The world produced about 275 MMT.¬† 2018-19 the US & brazil are in the 120MMT alone and the rest of the soybean producing countries are at roughly 350MMT. There is no price cause there is to much available. Looks like poor planning from year to year.¬†2012 also at the time¬†when the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) ended and millions of acres came back into production. Sure, farmers made a fortune a back then, but if they can't look ahead and see what is still on the market and figure that out, its not Trumps fault, taxpayers fault, its their fault. isn't the procuct coming out of south America easier to produce and cheaper. Until the cheaper product comes off the market there will be no price. Am I wrong? I looked this up on the internet and heard Dean Graner (a futures analyst)¬†on the radio talk about this during winter. There was plenty of time to plan ahead. They will get a subsidy payment to keep them going. In fact in 2010 every American paid $1200 in taxes to finance the farm bill. Yes, it is bipartisan too. People with barely enough money paid tax dollars to millionares in land and equipment because they can not make it. What did you get? Clinton created the current climate with trade because he thought china would become a more humanitarian country if it had money. How did that work out? Now Trump has to fix it. text:
@Miz Parker one of the continuing themes of American agriculture in the 20th century is a decline in the number of farms, farmers and rural residents coupled with an increase in the farm size, specialization and capitalization. The two decades between 1950 and 1970 were bellwether years for these trends.

Between 1950 and 1970, the number of farm declined by half before leveling off. More farms were consolidated or sold during this period than in any other period in our history.

The number of people on farms dropped from over 20 million in 1950 to less than 10 million in 1970.

The average size of farms went from around 205 acres in 1950 to almost 400 acres in 1969.

At the same time, productivity increased ‚Äì farmers were producing even more food at a cheaper cost to consumers on roughly the same amount of farmland in the country
author: Jack D

text:
Date:¬†August 11, 2015

New American Economy‚Äôs¬†new report, ‚ÄúA Vanishing Breed: How the Decline in U.S. Farm Laborers Over the Last Decade Has Hurt the U.S. Economy and Slowed Production on American Farms,‚Äù shows that in the last decade, as fewer young agricultural workers have come to the United States, the number of field and crop laborers available to farms has been rapidly declining. This drop has created a severe labor shortage in many key parts of the country vital to American farmers and iconic crops. It has also had an impact far beyond rural America: The lack of workers has not only hurt the ability of U.S. farms to grow and expand, it has cost our economy tens of thousands of jobs in related industries like trucking, marketing, and equipment manufacturing.
Findings include:
The supply of workers available to U.S. farmers has been rapidly declining.

Between 2002 and 2014, the number of full-time equivalent field and crop workers has dropped by at least 146,000 people, or by more than 20 percent. Wage patterns indicate that this caused a major labor shortage on U.S. farms.

The labor shortage has hurt our country‚Äôs ability to produce labor-intensive fruits, vegetables, and tree nuts.

Had labor shortages not been an issue, production of these crops could have been higher by about $3.1 billion a year. Given that farm revenues often trickle down to other industries in our economy, that $3.1 billion in additional farm production would have led to almost $2.8 billion in added spending on non-farm services like transportation, manufacturing, and irrigation each year. That spending would have created more than 41,000 additional non-farm jobs in our economy annually.

The number of potential farm workers immigrating to the United States has greatly slowed over the last decade.

Between 2002 and 2012, the number of new field and crop workers immigrating to the United States fell by roughly 75 percent. This led to a drop in the number of entry-level workers available for difficult jobs like hoeing, harvesting, and planting.

Some parts of the country were particularly hard hit by the recent labor decline.

The number of full-time equivalent field and crop workers in California declined by about 85,000 people between 2002 and 2014. The vast majority of this decline happened before the drought started in 2011. The southeastern part of the United States was also hard hit. Alabama, Georgia, and South Carolina lost about 8,500 workers total, or more than one in four of the crop workers employed in 2002. Colorado, Nevada, and Utah lost 36.7 percent of their full-time equivalent field workforce, or 7,029 people.

text: @Miz Parker agriculture is no riskier than many other industries, and it does not need an array of federal subsidies. Farm subsidies are costly to taxpayers, but they also harm the economy and the environment. Subsidies discourage farmers from innovating, cutting costs, diversifying their land use, and taking other actions needed to prosper in the competitive economy.
author: Jack D

text:
@Miz Parker Historically, farm bills have provided financial support for commodity crops (such as wheat, corn and soybeans) and no financial support for fruits and vegetables. Two types of subsidies given to commodity crop producers come in the form of¬†direct and counter-cyclicalpayments. ¬†Counter-cyclical payments are tied to market prices. Farmers will get paid when the price of their commodity is less than a price set by the government. Direct payments, on the other hand, are paid to a producer regardless of the market price of the crop. The payments are based on the number of acres the producer was growing when the subsidy program began.
The direct payments program allows a producer to plant anything he or she wants¬†except for¬†fruits and vegetables and still remain eligible to receive payments. Why would fruit and vegetable producers be excluded from receiving direct payments?
The short answer is that the fruit and vegetable producers did not want fruits and vegetables to be subsidized. A look back at Congressional records from the 1990 Farm Bill provides some interesting insight into how we got to where we are today.
1990: A ‚ÄúFlexible‚Äù Farm Bill
In 1990, the farm bill debate centered on whether to give farmers more flexibility in what they plant without jeopardizing their eligibility for farm payments. Traditionally, eligibility was based on a farmer‚Äôs ‚Äúhistorical planting patterns‚Äù so that if the farmer switched to a new crop, the farmer would lose eligibility for farm payments.
The notion of allowing a farmer to plant a different crop and remain eligible for payments, or¬†‚Äúdecoupling‚Äù¬†payments from production, was quite controversial. A June 14, 1990, Reuters article reported that the Senate Agriculture Committee rejected an amendment that would have allowed producers to rotate crops on 25 percent of their base acres without losing payments or program eligibility. Then-Senator Tom Daschle said, ‚ÄúThe issue is not flexibility. The issue is decoupling. I think it‚Äôs a big mistake from a policy standpoint.‚Äù
It‚Äôs About Flexibility: ¬†Any Program or Non-Program Crop
Despite Daschle‚Äôs disapproval, the July 6, 1990, Senate report included farm bill language that would have allowed producers the flexibility to plant any crop on 25 percent of their land without suffering a reduction in base acres used to determine payments.
If producers wanted to grow fruits or vegetables on a portion of their land, the producers would remain eligible for farm subsidies.
author: Jack D

text: @Miz Parker A perhaps unintended consequence of excluding themselves from the direct payments program is that fruit and vegetable producers have created a successful industry¬†without ever having received any subsidies, an experience that may prove crucial in the upcoming budget cuts.

text:
A negative trade balance is drain on a country's economy.  The U.S. has been hemorrhaging capital non-stop for over half a century.  Yes right now the trade war is hurting some segments of our economy but it is something we must go through to heal our weakened economic muscle.  Chemotherapy is hard as hell on a patient but it is often necessary to cure cancer and ultimately save that person's life.


I grew up raising cattle  It breaks my heart to see what most farm goods prices are.  But, in the end when we can once again see true full employment and we are exporting more than we import we will see these prices increase and it will be a lasting stable increase.
author: Raymond Bowersock

text: The United States HAS TO maintain a negative trade balance if we are to have the USD be the world's trade currency. Don't relate this to cancer - the two have nothing to do with one another...'so and so requires you to self-sabotage in order to have a chance at survival' is not some law of nature that must be applied to everything that you can just compare to trade because you think it sounds good.

It will never get to one hundred percent. As disheartening as that is, it‚Äôs only logical. There are many people out there across the socio-economic spectrum who are like Trump on a primal, basic level. They want what he has promised them and don‚Äôt care how he delivers it. We simply have to accept that not all ‚Äúbad‚Äù people are legally bad, some are ethically bad. We don‚Äôt have prisons for these people, we will have to deal with them within society. 

We may feel some people don‚Äôt deserve forgiveness for an act that causes so much harm but our feelings don‚Äôt change the fact that if we are to grow and advance as a society, or even a race (human, of course), we need to forgive each other, especially when we don‚Äôt want to. These are the times to apply logic before emotion, and to continue applying logic until compassion wins out over anger. It‚Äôs not fun, easy, or even gratifying but it is vitally necessary for our country to advance.

text:
Lawsuits 1973‚Äì1999	
Edit

Trump initially came to public attention in 1973 when he was accused by the Justice Department of violations of the Fair Housing Act in the operation of 39 buildings. The Department of Justice said that black "testers" were sent to more than half a dozen buildings and were denied apartments, but a similar white tester would then be offered an apartment in the same building.[9] The government alleged that Trump's corporation quoted different rental terms and conditions to blacks and made false "no vacancy" statements to blacks for apartments they managed in Brooklyn, Queens, and Staten Island.[10]

Representing Trump, Roy Cohn filed a counter-suit against the government for $100 million, asserting that the charges were irresponsible and baseless.[9][11] A federal judge threw out the countersuit, calling it a waste of "time and paper".[12] Trump settled the charges out of court in 1975 without admitting guilt, saying he was satisfied that the agreement did not "compel the Trump organization to accept persons on welfare as tenants unless as qualified as any other tenant".[13]

Tony Schwartz, the ghostwriter of Trump's book, The Art of the Deal, said that the housing case was "a classic example" of Trump being "a counterpuncher": someone accuses Trump of doing something horrible, and he "goes back at them with all guns blazing.... And admits nothing." If Trump loses, he will "declare victory".[14]

The corporation was required to send a bi-weekly list of vacancies to the New York Urban League, a civil rights group, and give them priority for certain locations.[15] In 1978 the Trump Organization again was in court for violating terms of the 1975 settlement; Trump denied the charges.

text:
Decades-Old Housing Discrimination Case Plagues Donald Trump


LISTEN¬∑ 5:17

Toggle more options
September 29, 201610:22 PM ET
Heard on All Things Considered
NPR STAFF

Donald Trump stands with New York Mayor Ed Koch, Gov. Hugh Carey and Robert T. Dormer of the Urban Development Corp. at the launching ceremony of the New York Hyatt Hotel in June 1978.
AP
During the presidential debate on Monday night, Hillary Clinton raised a 1973 federal lawsuit brought against Donald Trump and his company for alleged racial discrimination at Trump housing developments in New York.

The Justice Department sued Donald Trump, his father, Fred, and Trump Management in order to obtain a settlement in which Trump and his father would promise not to discriminate. The case eventually was settled two years later after Trump tried to countersue the Justice Department for $100 million for making false statements. Those allegations were dismissed by the court.

"Donald started his career, back in 1973, being sued by the Justice Department for racial discrimination ‚Äî because he would not rent apartments in one of his developments to African-Americans, and he made sure that the people who worked for him understood that was the policy," Clinton said on Monday night.

Clinton And Trump Clash In Tense First Presidential Debate 
POLITICS
Clinton And Trump Clash In Tense First Presidential Debate
Trump responded to Clinton by emphasizing that the case was settled with no admission of guilt.

"Yes, when I was very young, I went into my father's company ‚Äî had a real estate company in Brooklyn and Queens," Trump said. "And we, along with many, many other companies throughout the country ‚Äî it was a federal lawsuit ‚Äî were sued. We settled the suit with zero, with no admission of guilt."

The lawsuit was based on evidence gathered by testers for the New York City Human Rights Division, which alleged that black people who went to Trump buildings were told there were no apartments available, while white people were offered units.

Back then, Sheila Morse worked as one of those testers. When a black New Yorker was turned down for service and racial bias was suspected, Morse, who is white, would be dispatched to see if she received different treatment.

In this case, a black man in search of an apartment in Brooklyn in 1972 saw a sign on a building: "apartment for rent."

"He met with the superintendent, and the superintendent said, 'I'm very sorry, but the apartment is rented ‚Äî it's gone,' " Morse says. "So the gentlemen said to him, 'Well, why is the sign out? I still see a sign that says apartment for rent.' And the superintendent said, 'Oh, I guess I forgot to take it down.' "

How The Man Created The Brand In 'Trump Revealed'
POLITICS
How The Man Created The Brand In 'Trump Revealed'
When Morse went to the building to ask about the same apartment, she says, "They greeted me with open arms and showed me every aspect of the apartment."

Morse says she reported her experience to the Human Rights Commission, and then returned to the apartment building. After she was offered a lease, the black man who had tried to rent the apartment entered the office with a city human rights commissioner, and the three of them confronted the building superintendent.

"He said, 'Well, I'm only doing what my boss told me to do ‚Äî I am not allowed to rent to black tenants,' " Morse says.

The commissioner asked the building superintendent to take him to his boss. That turned out to be Trump Management.

Washington Post reporter Michael Kranish, co-author of the book Trump Revealed, tells NPR's Robert Siegel that the Justice Department considered the case "one of the most significant race bias cases" at the time.

It was a suit that was directly against them, and it is one that Donald Trump to this day clearly is upset about.
Michael Kranish
"They signed what was called a consent order," Kranish says. "Trump fought the case for two years. ... He says it was very easy, but actually he fought the case for two years."

The Trumps took essentially the first settlement offer the federal government provided, Kranish says; the Trumps did not, in fact, have to admit guilt in settling the suit.

"[The settlement] required the Trumps to place ads in newspapers saying that they welcomed black applicants," Kranish says. "It said that the Trumps would familiarize themselves with the Fair Housing Act, which prohibited discrimination. So it also specifically said they don't admit wrongdoing, but they did have to take several measures that the Trumps had fought for two years not to take."

Trump claims the Justice Department lawsuit was just one of many housing cases against many landlords, but Kranish says this description is misleading.

"Well, there were cases brought against various companies, but the point here is that Trump has said in the debate ‚Äî and he also told me when I interviewed him at Trump Tower earlier this year ‚Äî that this was part of one massive suit." Kranish says, "And in fact, this very specifically is a case that charges Donald Trump, Fred Trump and their company of race bias in housing rentals. ... It was one of the largest cases of the time. ...

"It was a suit that was directly against them, and it is one that Donald Trump to this day clearly is upset about."

text:
The Chinese government are upset that America is finally telling them to play fair.  Other presidents - Republican and Democrat haven't forced this issue.  The tarrifs on soybeans are China's way of trying to get back at the US.  This farmer isn't suffering because of Trump, he's suffering because of a decision made by the Chinese government - in response to a policy that will be good for America and the world long term.  
Metaphorically, China was a starving child.  Due to economic policy they have been allowed to take food off of the other plates of kids in the "cafeteria" (world) for a long time now.  China is now fat, and is being told they can't take food from others anymore (the US, Euro countries).  Of course they will be upset!  They want to keep eating!  What power do they have?  Their people like Soy products, and they have A LOT OF PEOPLE to buy them. So they throw a fit and use the weapons they have - tarriffs for Soy products.  This poor farmer is caught in the middle.  He's the good kid sitting across the table from the bad kid.  He accidentally gets hit with something.  Is it fair he got hit?  No.  But you don't blame the other guy who finally stands up to the bully fat kid - BLAME THE FAT KID WHO IS THROWING A FIT!  Why? So that he's finally forced to behave!  Don't placate the kid by giving him a treat to shut him up (another trade deal).  MAKE HIM BEHAVE!


I hope this doesn't get lost in an echo chamber...

text:
Former national security adviser Michael Flynn told investigators that people linked to the Trump administration and Congress reached out to him in an effort to interfere in the Russia probe, according to newly-unredacted court papers filed Thursday.

The court filing from special counsel Robert Mueller is believed to mark the first public acknowledgement that a person connected to Capitol Hill was suspected of engaging in an attempt to impede the investigation into Russian election interference.

‚ÄúThe defendant informed the government of multiple instances, both before and after his guilty plea, where either he or his attorneys received communications from persons connected to the Administration or Congress that could‚Äôve affected both his willingness to cooperate and the completeness of that cooperation,‚Äù the court papers say.

Flynn even provided a voicemail recording of one such communication, the court papers say.

text:
Senator Cotton is a cotton pickin' damn fool; he's just another evil warmonger without his own set of core principles, and that is why I believe he couldn't make a career in the military as a leader.  He's another Trump-worshiping flunky, lackey who just wants to stay in power as a senator.  He'll never obtain any powerful governmental leadership job beyond senator.  Very few minorities would vote for any Republican in leadership today, even if they were to switch party to the Democratic Party.


This farmer that is being interviewed, and others like him, thought he saw more in Trump than a person who could help his business; he thought he saw white power and intelligence too; however, because things are not going so well for his livelihood, his business seems to trumps white power--no pun intended.  Additionally, all of the right-wing business people see the same as this farmer saw in Trump, and most of them are doing extremely well with the exception of agriculture, coal and mining businesses.  People with 401Ks, including myself, are doing better than average to outstanding with regard to our money making money. 


I've always considered stock to be somewhat fake money making money and that is why people lose so much of it when the stock market crashes.  Making easy money on stock during times like these when the world's economy is doing well could give one a sense of utmost confidence and satisfaction; howbeit, when the stock market begins to crash hard, a sudden and eerie heart-wrenching sensation just seems to enveloped you for days, knowing you had a false sense of security that that money wasn't going to be there for a very long time, but you took a chance anyway--other words, you gambled and you lost!  I believe there will be another serious stock crisis soon--either in mid-2020 or within the first cycle quarter of 2021.  We haven't had a real masses of people dying type of war yet, and if we have the kind of war we had like WW-I and WW-II where millions of people died, I don't think the stock market could rebound so easily.  China won't do me a favor soon enough!

text:
I'm no fan of Donald Trump. In point of fact, I've loathed the man for 40 years and did not vote for him. I didn't vote for his Democratic opponent either. As far as I'm concerned both major parties did the nation a monumental disservice by putting two untrustworthy people on the stump.
As for China, trade restrictions, tariffs and embargoes have always been in the toolbag of statecraft. This ain't nuthin' new, folks.  And every POTUS has used them in one form or another. China has been waging an undeclared economic war against the US for 75 years. She has repeatedly stolen trade secrets, refuses to recognize copyright laws, manipulated markets to effect the US economy, and has been relentlessly attacking our internet infrastructure. That's not hyperbole, that's historical fact. And everybody from the CIA and the FBI all the way down to Dept. of Labor will tell you so.
So, I don't like Trump. He's a serial sexual predator, a failed businessman, an embarrassment as a leader, and lousy human being. Were he to run for reelection I would not vote for him. HOWEVER, China and it's trade practices are an issue that has needed addressing for decades.

actually lets list the accomplishments


Almost 4 million jobs created since election.
More Americans are now employed than ever recorded before in our history.

Median household income has hit highest level ever recorded.
African-American unemployment has recently achieved the lowest rate ever recorded.
Hispanic-American unemployment is at the lowest rate ever recorded.
Asian-American unemployment recently achieved the lowest rate ever recorded.

Under my Administration, veterans‚Äô unemployment recently reached its lowest rate in nearly 20 years.
Almost 3.9 million Americans have been lifted off food stamps since the election.

95 percent of U.S. manufacturers are optimistic about the future‚Äîthe highest ever.
Retail sales surged last month, up another 6 percent over last year.
Signed the biggest package of tax cuts and reforms in history. After tax cuts, over $300 billion poured back in to the U.S. in the first quarter alone.
As a result of our tax bill, small businesses will have the lowest top marginal tax rate in more than 80 years.

Helped win U.S.-Mexico-Canada‚Äôs united bid for 2026 World Cup.
Opened ANWR and approved Keystone XL and Dakota Access Pipelines.
Record number of regulations eliminated.

Obamacare individual mandate penalty GONE.

Last month, the FDA approved more affordable generic drugs than ever before in history. And thanks to our efforts, many drug companies are freezing or reversing planned price increases.
We reformed the Medicare program to stop hospitals from overcharging low-income seniors on their drugs‚Äîsaving seniors hundreds of millions of dollars this year alone.
Signed Right-To-Try legislation.

We have reduced high-dose opioid prescriptions by 16 percent during my first year in office.
Signed VA Choice Act and VA Accountability Act, expanded VA telehealth services, walk-in-clinics, and same-day urgent primary and mental health care.
Increased our coal exports by 60 percent; U.S. oil production recently reached all-time high.

NATO allies are spending $69 billion more on defense since 2016.

Withdrew from the horrible, one-sided Iran Deal.

Protecting Americans from terrorists with the Travel Ban, upheld by Supreme Court.

Reached a breakthrough agreement with the E.U. to increase U.S. exports.

Imposed tariffs on China in response to China‚Äôs forced technology transfer, intellectual property theft, and their chronically abusive trade practices.

Especilly the lie that tariffs are paid by the consumers. Yes u may end up paying more. But that is just the price going back up to where everyone other manufacturer is at. The price is only low to start with because The Imports (such as steel) are being dumped below cost in order to put our manufacturers out of business. Its a common Business tactic.
Example: Cost of steel to make Widget here is 10 dollars (with like 10% profit for the company). An importer brings in steel for $5 (at a loss). The steel makers here can't compete so they close shop. Imported steel goes up to $12 because they are the only source.
Same situation but with tariffs: Government puts $5 tariff on Imports. Their steel is now same as Ours. You can buy either one and the consumer pays nothing extra. Our steel manufacturers stay in business. The Government would only be taking $5 of ur money IF the manufacturer still bought imported steel.
If the tariff is $6 dollars so now imports are higher than Domestic steel. Now everyone would be buying domestic and NO tariff fees go to government. <--- this is the desired outcome.

Now the problem is that China (and others) have been selling cheap here in the USA for YEARS. And yes we get cheap stuff that way. BUT our domestic companies close shop, people out of work and New Companies never get started because they can't compete.

Tariffs can generally raise prices but it levels out after a while. This hurst some, but in the long run Domestic is better. I remember the days when Import stood for something exotic, different. it dosens work that way today.

Regarding how it effects the American Farmers and the economy:

(1) The tariffs are cutting the prices nearly 30% to 50% depending on product meaning much less money for quanity.

(2) This is causing the Farmers to increase their prices to a major level just so they can survive in overhead. Food is a necessity & need, it is not a want so of course the prices are effecting the American consumer as it's effecting the Farmers. 

(3) Everyone sees the prices increased in our grocery stores. I hope all Americans remember these prices going up in the 2020 elections on how Trump is severely hurting our domestic economy. Trump is killing our financial freedom, not helping us at all. He needs to be impeached and or removed by 2020. 

I am saying this as a independent voter and consumer. I am not saying this as a Democrat or Republican as I keep a open mind not by party but by the needs of the Americans.

@Seth Portland you seem to be conflating Trump and the Republican party as a whole, here: the trend is for Republican lawmakers to be in the pocket of the private prisons industry(some of them due due to ideological reasons such as believing the claim that private prisons cost less, other because they're getting lobbyist $$$ or because they own shares in some prison corporations), and just because one Republican, no matter how prominent, doesn't follow the trend due to his own interests or whims does no change that fact.


I'm not suggesting getting rid of prisons entirely, but I sure as fuck want the for-profit prison industry gone yesterday! The profits of these evil fucks rely on a steady supply of inmates to use as de facto slaves, so they're lobbying for bullshit laws that will keep their prisons (and their pockets) full. They'll also cut every corner they can, resulting in unsanitary, dangerous prisons, and actively oppose initiatives that might reduce recidivism as it would also reduce their business... Prisons should be under the control of the government, not shareholders, and they need some major reforms to focus on actually rehabilitating inmates. text:
@Mister J aren't you a bit old to still be believing in Trickle Down Santa?


It is a well-established fact that the lion's share of corporate tax cuts and subsidies end up as stock-buybacks, bonuses and dividends for the shareholders instead of getting reinvested into the economy. The Trump tax cuts for example have lead to a round of stock buybacks and haven't prevented major layoffs by some of the main beneficiaries of said tax cuts.


Hell, even when the corporations do invest some of that money into their business, it is often to automatise and/or delocalise, which if anything tends to destroy jobs, or at least domestic jobs...


As for me calling the Grifting Old Party "Rethuglicans", I fail to see what the problem with calling people "thugs" would be, considering said people have been mugging the middle and working class for the benefit of their corporate masters since at least the Reagan years.

text:
@@Ian Buell  Correct... he is the  PresentResident of the WH.  Years ago I went to a casino. When I walked in there were colorful lights flashing, all kinds of bells going off,  the sound of coins falling and it kind of got the ole' adrenaline going. I was excited and looking forward to that "big jackpot."  I finally settled on a machine and began to put some money in and pulled the lever. There were people around me doing the same thing all hoping for a big win as well, I'm sure.  This is before the paper slip payouts... I had 2 cups, a play cup and a keep cup. When I won, I put part in the play cup and part in the keep cup. As long as I had money in the play cup, I played. When the funds were gone, I took my keep cup and just enjoyed the sights, sounds and food.


 Here's the thing. What appeared to be machines paying off all over the place and the sounds of coins falling and people winning was an illusion. If you put $20 in a machine and it gives you  0.75 is that really a win even if the lights flash and the bells go off?   That is what trump represents to me. The promise of a big payday, but a .75 payout.  A carnival barker, a snake-oil salesman.  


I appreciate the candor of the farmer and respect him for acknowledging what he expected and what he got as opposed to what he was told he would get.  I takes a smart person to  know what he doesn't know and surround himself with people who have the expertise and knowledge that they lack and trump is NOT that person.  Perhaps things are going great for you and that's awesome. For every person who says things are great, there are many more who things are not going so great for.  It's going great for trump because he is profiting, majorly.  


When I think of real billionaires, I think of Warren Buffet, Bill Gates and Oprah...when you have it you don't have to try to convince people of how great you are, typically they do what they do without fanfare. In my humble opinion, trump is an insecure man-child, a liar, and a con-man. There is no question that he has or had more money than I will ever see in my lifetime, and I'm fine with that. He was elected as the PresentResident.
The challenges I face may be far different than a farmer or a coal-miner, but I can still have empathy for their plight. One's problems doesn't negate the problems of someone else. Therein lies our humanity... which sadly  seems to be eroding daily under this administration.


This was just my 2.15 worth. We can respectfully agree to disagree on the subject of trump.

Tariffs are only for short term gain, but Trump believes its an end game scenario.

As for the Southern border even democrats have been pushing for reform and to bolster up immigration policy and any informed person knows they dont believe in open borders, that's absurd. text: @Alex S Well Alex it is not that simple. Insurance companies set the standard for what care they will pay for and the length of time they will pay regardless of the care needed. This is true for individual policies and group policies as well. Except in emergency situations all treatments must be APPROVED for payment by the insurance company who will not only determine what they will pay but whether on not the procedure that the doctor is contemplating is NECESSARY. In other words some fucking bean counter that you have never met is deciding the course of your medical care, rather than your own doctor. Also you will find that not only will your premiums rise almost annually but prices will vary significantly for medications. Sometimes they go up and sometimes down but mostly up and sometimes by a LOT.  Furthermore not all businesses have to provide health insurance and business can bargain with insurance companies to craft plans that the business can afford. That means that many necessary procedures or medications may not be insured and you won't be informed of that fact until you or your doctor call them to have a procedure or medication approved.  I know , I've been there. My daughter has been going to Mayo Clinic for the past seven or eight years and recently got a bill for a procedure that she was told had been approved. Unfortunately the hospital sent the wrong code and as a result the insurance company retroactively denied payment and sent her a bill for $3000.00 for a process that would have cost her S300.00 if  covered.  After 6 months of haggling with both, neither will admit to their mistake and told her she would have to sue.

text:
Either you don't know business or you are lying CNN (fake news anyone). If you went to business school you would know about something called "price elasticity". If you put a tax on McDonalds but not Burger King, and McDonalds raises their prices- everyone will just eat at burger king. The cost to consumers will be minimal. Thus McDonalds must eat most of the tax. This is what we are doing to China. Yes some small percentage of it will go into higher prices or higher cost on the American side, but the majority of the cost is being paid by China. 


Which by the way- China has been doing this to us for decades and has been enjoying 10% and 20% annual growth while we consider 2% growth a good year. So if it is such bad economic policy you'll have to tell that to all these other countries that have been sticking America with high tariffs for decades.

I am an accountant for a government agency currently, but worked my way up from many industries, including Bovine slaughterhouse, Yard worker at a garden/bulk construction operator, truck driver, heavy machinery operator, and into a professional career. But you are FOS if you think a small farm has enough money for a $500,000 machine.  It just wouldn't be economical to have a yearly profit in sales of a few thousand dollars and purchase a machine that costs that much.  Sorry.

text: This interview is somewhat disingenuous.  This farmer knows the main reason Soybeans are down in Price has very little to do with tariffs and trade War with China. There is a glut of Soybeans around the globe.  In addition, China is experiencing a swine flu among their herd of pigs that has wiped out one third of stock with no end in sight.  Because of this, China's purchase of Soybeans has slowed significantly, less need for Bean Meal, the feed for pigs.  Even if the tariffs were removed, they'd still be in a fix. Also, the President did not question his patriotism, he in fact praised it. Where the money comes from to help the farmers is a moot point, especially when it comes to the way our government is run, and that doesn't fall only on the President.  The Congress holds the purse strings.   In the end, its all about the spin and not the facts.

text: I think most people don't understand how tariffs work.  The American people do pay the tariffs, but the countries that are selling the goods don't get to sell them in America because the prices become too high.  So places like China are greatly affected because their sales drop and Americans find better sources of goods either here or elsewhere.   A tariff does not mean we don't want trade with China.  It means we want a better deal with China.  They have been taking advantage of us for decades.  When China cannot sell in America because the tariffs make their products cost too much their economy goes down just like it is doing now.  Trump is right it puts us in a better negotiating position.   I am sorry for this farmer that he is having so much trouble BUT understand that all businesses are ultimately responsible for their own business.  I have never liked farm subsidies.  If food cost more it just cost more.  It is a socialistic practice to give farmers subsidies.  It lowers food prices for everyone but the intent is not to help farmers, it is to make food more affordable for poor people.  Increase their food stamp benefits directly and let the farmers learn to manage their businesses on free market principals.  This farmer is ANGRY but he ADMITS he took the money (subsidy).  He is a hypocrite.

text:
How are Trump Tarifs working for you ? ü§£ ü§£ ü§£ ü§£ ü§£ ü§£ 

Trumps import tariffs on Chinese goods threaten to hit American consumers in particular. If the trade war escalates further, the conflict can make a considerable number of consumer goods more expensive.

For example, not only Chinese clothing and bags become more expensive for American consumers due to the higher import duties, but also fire alarms, laptops and furniture (pdf). And so far, a large proportion of consumer goods that the US imports have not been taken into consideration.

But if Trump continues with a 25 percent tax on almost all Chinese goods, as he has threatened, then more and more Americans will be confronted with higher prices of all kinds of products.
Research into the first wave of higher import tariffs shows that the extra tax of 10 percent was then mainly passed on to the American consumer. The American importers were also sometimes hit, but foreign exporters would still get the same price.
$ 69 billion extra paid by import tariffs
A group of economists calculated that consumers paid 69 billion dollars (more than 61 billion euros) through all import tariffs that the US introduced last year. This also includes taxes on steel and aluminum.

Trump claims that China will pay the taxes. According to his reasoning, Chinese companies must lower their prices to remain competitive. But probably Trump relies on historical figures, economist David Weinstein of Columbia University in New York told Bloomberg. In practice, it appears that Chinese and other foreign companies have not lowered their prices.
A closer look at the figures also shows that the damage on the American side is mainly suffered in areas that voted Republican. This was mainly due to retaliatory actions by other countries that scoffed at the American agricultural sector.

text:
Decades-Old Housing Discrimination Case Plagues Donald Trump


LISTEN¬∑ 5:17

Toggle more options
September 29, 201610:22 PM ET
Heard on All Things Considered
NPR STAFF

Donald Trump stands with New York Mayor Ed Koch, Gov. Hugh Carey and Robert T. Dormer of the Urban Development Corp. at the launching ceremony of the New York Hyatt Hotel in June 1978.
AP
During the presidential debate on Monday night, Hillary Clinton raised a 1973 federal lawsuit brought against Donald Trump and his company for alleged racial discrimination at Trump housing developments in New York.

The Justice Department sued Donald Trump, his father, Fred, and Trump Management in order to obtain a settlement in which Trump and his father would promise not to discriminate. The case eventually was settled two years later after Trump tried to countersue the Justice Department for $100 million for making false statements. Those allegations were dismissed by the court.

"Donald started his career, back in 1973, being sued by the Justice Department for racial discrimination ‚Äî because he would not rent apartments in one of his developments to African-Americans, and he made sure that the people who worked for him understood that was the policy," Clinton said on Monday night.

Trump responded to Clinton by emphasizing that the case was settled with no admission of guilt.

"Yes, when I was very young, I went into my father's company ‚Äî had a real estate company in Brooklyn and Queens," Trump said. "And we, along with many, many other companies throughout the country ‚Äî it was a federal lawsuit ‚Äî were sued. We settled the suit with zero, with no admission of guilt."

The lawsuit was based on evidence gathered by testers for the New York City Human Rights Division, which alleged that black people who went to Trump buildings were told there were no apartments available, while white people were offered units.

Back then, Sheila Morse worked as one of those testers. When a black New Yorker was turned down for service and racial bias was suspected, Morse, who is white, would be dispatched to see if she received different treatment.

In this case, a black man in search of an apartment in Brooklyn in 1972 saw a sign on a building: "apartment for rent."

"He met with the superintendent, and the superintendent said, 'I'm very sorry, but the apartment is rented ‚Äî it's gone,' " Morse says. "So the gentlemen said to him, 'Well, why is the sign out? I still see a sign that says apartment for rent.' And the superintendent said, 'Oh, I guess I forgot to take it down.' "

How The Man Created The Brand In 'Trump Revealed'
POLITICS
How The Man Created The Brand In 'Trump Revealed'
When Morse went to the building to ask about the same apartment, she says, "They greeted me with open arms and showed me every aspect of the apartment."

Morse says she reported her experience to the Human Rights Commission, and then returned to the apartment building. After she was offered a lease, the black man who had tried to rent the apartment entered the office with a city human rights commissioner, and the three of them confronted the building superintendent.

"He said, 'Well, I'm only doing what my boss told me to do ‚Äî I am not allowed to rent to black tenants,' " Morse says.

The commissioner asked the building superintendent to take him to his boss. That turned out to be Trump Management.

Washington Post reporter Michael Kranish, co-author of the book Trump Revealed, tells NPR's Robert Siegel that the Justice Department considered the case "one of the most significant race bias cases" at the time.

It was a suit that was directly against them, and it is one that Donald Trump to this day clearly is upset about.
Michael Kranish
"They signed what was called a consent order," Kranish says. "Trump fought the case for two years. ... He says it was very easy, but actually he fought the case for two years."

The Trumps took essentially the first settlement offer the federal government provided, Kranish says; the Trumps did not, in fact, have to admit guilt in settling the suit.

"[The settlement] required the Trumps to place ads in newspapers saying that they welcomed black applicants," Kranish says. "It said that the Trumps would familiarize themselves with the Fair Housing Act, which prohibited discrimination. So it also specifically said they don't admit wrongdoing, but they did have to take several measures that the Trumps had fought for two years not to take."

Trump claims the Justice Department lawsuit was just one of many housing cases against many landlords, but Kranish says this description is misleading.

"Well, there were cases brought against various companies, but the point here is that Trump has said in the debate ‚Äî and he also told me when I interviewed him at Trump Tower earlier this year ‚Äî that this was part of one massive suit." Kranish says, "And in fact, this very specifically is a case that charges Donald Trump, Fred Trump and their company of race bias in housing rentals. ... It was one of the largest cases of the time. ...

"It was a suit that was directly against them, and it is one that Donald Trump to this day clearly is upset about."

text:
@Kenneth Alexander, thanks for your kind response. I feel nobody's really qualified to be president to be honest. He is just like most of them I guess. I still don't know Trump at all, and I probably never will because of the simple fact that I never met him. Don't know the guy other then just watching stuff about him and doing my own 'background-research', like you. 
I couldn't care less about Trump to be honest. 
But I really do like almost everything in the world that happens BECAUSE of Trump. It's hilarious, deep, interesting, human research worthy, confirming, exposing etc. etc., hence my comment. Great stuff! People are definitely drawn out of their comfort-zones, a good thing to progress as humans I feel. Reading your post you probably think that people are waking up to the danger and craziness of Trump and his posse and that we're on the brink of something terrible. Fair enough. I think that a lot of stuff is already being exposed and maybe some more is there to come. Let's see whose 'crystal ball' is more accurate. 
To hell with the division, let's transcend the party-thinking, let's observe the (verbal and physical and intellectual) violence, let's be aware of the pains we people have to go through to get somewhere constructive and, again, transcending. 
The decisions and people from America's ''new'' administration and president, so far, are not worse than the decisions and people from former administrations and presidents, in my humble opinion; We can argue about that till the cows come home obviously but I feel that will always remain a personal thing; The so-called facts and evidences, in my opinion again, are often highly overrated because most people have the tendency to pick out that stuff that suits and justifies their own, conditioned or 'put in by others' believes and narrative. And, on the other hand, people in powerful positions all over the world the last 5,000 years, and especially those who 'govern' others, have been lying their asses of to stay in those positions. Nothing new under the sun.
Anyway, I guess the decisions from this administration, where you and I form our opinions partly on, are just brought a little different; Probably less subtle or sneaky, less in a way people are used to (not) hear or find out about them, less politically substantiated and more in the face of the people, due to that. New Yorkers?
And of course the anxious need to find something negative around those decisions, from, mostly, the mainstream media and/or shows like this one, also helps bringing them to the public. 
Discussions/opinions about those national and international decisions will be more interesting and find a broader foundation/audience and will increase the awareness of human beings about these decisions, and the importance of law-making and government(s)-behavior in general, no matter which side your on (let's stay nicely conditioned in our own 'duality-thinking', right?); A good thing I guess, in spite of the increasing heated arguments, name-calling, bad jokes, easy jokes, preconditioned thoughts, ideas and statements and so on surrounding it.... 
An increased and/or increasing awareness eventually always leads to a decrease of tensions, although the tensions, often stronger felt than before, unavoidable have to come to the surface first (from any direction), to dissolve afterwards; If they stay under the surface they can be covered up, but they'll always be there.
author: Marc Jacobs

text:
@Marc Jacobs I understand your point and thank you for being polite. While I agree that the political institutions and citizenry of the United States needed a wake up call, I don't agree that you have to break something for it to be improved. Perhaps I'm in the minority and people do need something to break for them to pay attention to it. Only a fortune teller would know.

My concern is not with the economy. A bad economy is just the difference between owning a Lexus and owning a Toyota. The market will always cycle and right itself one way or another. 

My concern is with foreign relations and the one duty (of many) of the President to be Commander in Chief. The current president doesn't have public administration experience, diplomatic experience, or military experience. All of these necessary to lead the diplomatic corps and the armed forces. 

If you mess up in business (as he has done multiple times) you file bankruptcy, get a tax break, and start over. If you mess up diplomacy, people die.

So again, I have nothing personal against the man but for the most important job in our country and one of the most important around the world, I would prefer someone qualified. Someone with a professional manner that has experience and takes the job seriously.

text:
@Mike Cziraky 
My "outrage" as you put it, would be characterized in the constant lies and disinformation being spewed through hate and ignorance. 

The homes you speak of that were lost initially under President Obama's tenure were due to the FAILED policies of the Bush/Cheney administration. 
Wall Street was unleashed on the taxpayers in every conceivable way possible. They raided pensions, improperly rating bonds - scoring them as top AAAA ratings when they were worthless paper and THIS in turn caused MANY to lose their homes under these horrible subprime loans, which were definitely driven  by greed.
When Bush came into office, Republicans almost immediately lobbied to lift the Glass/Stiegel Act. This was a measure put into place as a provisions of the United States Banking Act of 1933 separating commercial and investment banking. This was done to ensure that the collapse that happened in the stock market crash back then, would never repeat itself. Republicans knew this and proceeded to remove these protections anyway!

In other words, this act protected the citizens and the country from situations that we found ourselves in again in 2007 BEFORE President Obama was elected. 

AND I must also mention how they SQUANDERED an actual SURPLUS left by President Clinton's Administration. Further, they started an unnecessary AND unfunded war. However, they did fund the very banksters that robbed the country blind and caused these people you speak of to be thrown out on the streets!!!
Everything President Obama did to try and help those affected - they obstructed. Do we see a theme going on here?! 

So let's be very clear - President Obama saved this country from the brink of disaster and as a result, also many other nations in the world's economy from total collapse. And THAT IS A FACT.
He did great things and could have done more if hate weren't so blinding and destructive.

If you want to make points about such critical discussions and matters; please come armed with the truth. Contrary to what some espouse, truth and facts actually do STILL MATTER.

Have a nice day.

text:
Chinese farmers grow over 21 million hectares of #soybean

Farmers across China have planted about 21 million hectares of soybean to date, accounting for 37.6% of the country‚Äôs total crop area, as farmers respond to the country‚Äôs soybean revitalization campaign.

Nearly 56 million hectares of various crops have been planted across China, achieving more than 60% of the goal. Among them, soybean accounts for 37.6% of the total, according to data released by the Agriculture and Rural Affairs Ministry.

Specifically, China‚Äôs Heilongjiang province saw a significant increase in soybean growth.

Known as the ‚Äúhometown of soybeans,‚Äù the soybean planting area in Hailun, Heilongjiang, reached nearly 174,000 hectares, an increase of 40,000 hectares compared to last year, according to Wang Baofeng, deputy mayor of the city.

Government subsidies for soybeans and higher market prices have stimulate the growth in rural areas. As a result, farmers are choosing to sow soybean seeds instead of other crops, said a local farmer, who planted 100 hectares of soybeans on his land.

At the beginning of this year, the Chinese government issued its soybean revitalization plan, a plan to expand the planting area for soybeans across China. The country aims to increase the area to 9 million hectares by 2020 and to 10 million hectares by 2022.

text:
@Jason Engelbrecht     China is the bully on the block. As long as you play their game they will be nice to you. Sure consumers will pay more for Chinese goods but the manufacturing base moved to China or Mexico. That was bad for the US worker along with competition from illeagals for jobs that have lowered wages. 

China wants to be the #1 superpower and is securing raw materials and resources from other countries. They claim all of the China Sea which infuriates the other countries that are in the China Sea. They often capture Chinese fishing boats fishing in their waters. 
China has 51% controlling interest in all foreign factories,joint venture partnerships,ect. China also claims the intellectual properties of these foriegn partnerships so they can use them in new and existing Chinese companies. The military can start and own businesses to help fund their military needs.
I have been to China 8 times and spent a little over 6 months there. If my Chinese friends want to say how they really feel about their govt they would go down an alley it make sure that others in public would not hear them. One of my friends in Kunming said when she was going to college some of her friends went to Beijing for the protest in Tiananmen Square. She never saw or heard from them again. 
Trump is doing what is best in the long term by taking on these unfair trade deals. And the tens of millions of illeagals that have poured in the US over the last few decades hurt American workers. They do lower the costs for employers,but decrease the standard of living for the blue collar workers in many sectors if the labor market. 
I went back to driving a truck all over the US but 3 years ago I was working in Texas as a supervisor in a construction related bussiness. They payed the workers $8.30 an hour to dig ditches and work in the hot Texas climate. They never had a problem finding workers and they were from Central America and Mexico. When I worked those types of jobs decades ago the pay would be $12-13 an hour in today's market.

text:
The result of voting for a loose cannon such as Trump is that you have to expect collateral damage from wild fire.  In international reputation, US government treasury wealth, global stability (in both climate and extremism in particular) and trust in democracy the US is in a free fall.  You wanted something done, well this is something.  Most have secured the devil's bargain, destroy fundamental US principles of democracy and stability in order to secure gains in what they perceive to be fundamental goals of religious conservatism (abortion and women's rights), social conservatism (essentially anti-immigration - anti ethnic policy dressed up as security) and corporate domination (dressed as free market capitalism against the specter of socialist agenda).  The prevailing belief was we got what we want in terms of resetting the US social order to a 1950's utopia that never really existed and how much damage can Trump's wilder impulses possibly do?......    
Yeah, turns out a lot.  The thing is Trump and MAGA supporters, if you sell your soul, then crying when the Devil comes to collect the debt is not going to help much.  And the problem is, you did not sell your individual souls, you traded the collective ideals of tolerance, freedom and democratic inclusion which allegedly the US nation stood for.  When you did not like the nature of the freedom granted by those ideals, its progressive policy and charitable support - you voted for a man who is burning it all down.  Time to toast the marsh mellows in the ruins I guess.

text:
Farmers are businessmen. Soldiers are technically government paid employees... every American is a patriot , so long as they believe in and support the country (not necessarily the government, but the country)... 

But to shove an unwilling and unplanned financial sacrifice on a businessman, isn‚Äôt the same as a government paid employee going to Iraq. 

And to damage their market and hinder their ability to generate money for themselves, their families, and their employees, in the name of what is really just Trump trying to appease his ego, isn‚Äôt patriotic. 

We are all victims of collateral damage because this wasn‚Äôt a measured effort... Just something Trump & Co. did on a whim... to possibly boost his numbers. And it‚Äôs going to be felt in every market and industry before it‚Äôs all said and done.

And you can‚Äôt ask people who are living week to week, month to month, or even year to year to bare a ‚Äúshort-term sacrifice‚Äù for several years... 

because by the time thing get to where Trump wants with China and every other country, tens of thousands of small businesses and the hundreds of thousands of people they employ won‚Äôt be in business to reap the benefits. Only the absolute strongest and largest are going to be able to make it... they‚Äôll probably absorb some of the smaller farms... 

But Trump doesn‚Äôt think about these things.

text:
The economy is doing better than ever before in the U.S....and farmer's are complaining that the free market isn't free enough due to tariffs? Sounds to me like U.S. farmers need to be innovative in finding better existing market opportunities instead of appealing to the most competitive and cheapest market previously available to them. I understand feeling the pinch of losing financial access to China, but to try to argue that American farmers are so dependent on China that farming is no longer a profitable or viable business venture under these conditions is absurd.
Yeah, there's obviously been some disruption in the market, but that's an obvious consequence of this trade policy, and farmers affected by it should be pro-active in figuring out where they need to reach out to in order to compensate for these changes in market conditions.
Confidence can only be built upon when the market reaches a point of predictability and stability, and President Trump lost confidence in the fairness of China as a fair trading partner. Instead of complaining about it, Americans should be adamant about ensuring that Chinese trade policy benefits American citizens of all occupations.

text: Legislators of both parties have always loved welfare for the rich...but they call it something else like "Tax Relief", "Subsidy", "Research Grant",  "Economic Stimulus", etc.and then they justify it with "Trickle Down" and "Growth Projections".  But, when someone like Sanders supports giving assistance to those in need, they call him a Socialist which he honestly admits, and they call poor people parasites...the difference is that Sanders would stop a lot of the welfare for the wealthy and use it instead to provide a basis safety net for everyone in terms of essential needs and education.  The kind of Socialism Sanders wants is not a matter of government handing out more, it is a matter of handing it out where it is needed and where it actually will be an investment in the future.  And, what Sanders wants is not a government takeover of the means of production or discarding free-market capitalism...he just wants it regulated enough to keep it fair and to keep us safe.  Unregulated Capitalism run-amok is very destructive...ultimately self-destructive.  All competitive sports need referees and umpires and rules...and a Capitalist economic system is very much the same in that regard.

The employee's wife would have a fit just as the shareholders and owners of businesses would if managers used that strategy and under the rules that govern corporations would be legal grounds for shareholders to file legal action to seek and win monetary  compensation for their loss. Do you remember how Japanese motorcycle companies tried that tactic in the '70's to win market share from Harley-Davidson? That caused the US to impose huge tariffs on Japanese bikes over 700cc. The Japs changed their strategy to using high technology coupled with a highly educated, skilled workforce and modern manufacturing process to make a superior product at a lower cost. text:
"The President has been very clear that all of these tariff dollars that he wants to transfer to farmers are coming in from China. That's just not true!"  --- Well looky here. A farmer, one of thousands who voted for Trump (a group who invariably always vote Conservative no matter what) is finally waking up from the kool-aid and realizing his Orange Overlord is a liar. Sad that it takes having a hit directly to their own pocketbook before these guys start coming out saying mistakes are being made. Shame that over ten thousand lies from their President can be ignored and even in some instances DEFENDED, but this here particular lie is where they draw the line.

Look, it's great to see a guy like this "telling it like it is". He and any of his agriculture cohorts are very much welcome on board the sane train. But damn, people, can we not do better than this -- refusing to see a President for what he so is until his stupidity finally comes around to negatively affecting you? With some of the Trumpers out there it's as if the entire rest of the country could be falling in on itself but as long as "I'm" okay it's Trump all the way!

Bravo to this guy for speaking out. Better late than never I say. Hopefully more from his line of work step up as well. You guys may take some heat like I've just given you, but make no mistake your open candor now is heart-warming, and tells me that there is yet hope for the future, if more like you just...wake....up.

Note to Trump: yes Mr. President, handing out billions to any industry to make up for fallout from your backfiring policies is very much a form of socialism. If it flies in the face of the spirit of pure capitalism that you espouse, and it does, then it most assuredly has an aspect of socializing the economy. You and your horde of minions will, of course, replace it with the word "stabilizing", trying to paint over the glaring truth, and your remaining FOX-watching everTrumpers will eat it up and repeat it like it's gospel. Rinse-repeat.

Only a rational outcome in 2020 will save everyone from this merry-go-round of madness.
author: CD Smith

author: TITUS TITUS

text:
@Jacob Selmon sorry to reply so much it's hard to explaining these texts. U.S
 CONSUMER REPORTS the fact we are trying to point out.
 I agree with you when the Tariffs were not as high as they are now. The statistics now show U.S. Products would  be the same price with the tariffs in place. Right now today. The problem is the companies are using the Tariffs to raise their Price to make more money, they are use to the amount of products they make or the market share they had before the Tariffs so they see it as a way to increase profits, not sell more product.
Which is what we need. More products sold not a higher price point.
If we as business owners stuck to our prices before we would see a huge market share gain for us.
author: TITUS TITUS

text:
TITUS TITUS you‚Äôre missing my point. Today, prices are lower because US manufacturers and retailers purchase products from foreign companies. The same products made in the US are more expensive. What tariffs do is essentially force American consumers (which includes everyone in the US) to pay higher prices, because they‚Äôre either buying newly taxed foreign goods, or inherently more expensive American goods. By benefiting some areas of the economy, tariffs sacrifice the wellbeing of everyone. The whole situation gets worse when you add the fact that China isn‚Äôt a punching bag. They‚Äôre already hitting back with tariffs of their own, and US exporters, particularly of agricultural products, are getting hurt, as prices of their products in China rise, and Chinese businesses and consumers turn to products made elsewhere. 
In summary, tariffs raise prices for all Americans, and cause many American exporters to China to lose business.

text:
I'm tired of old tired news being called breaking news. If we don't have established companies in the USA, already producing the items that will receive a tariffs, it will not benefit the consumer. Even then the company that is manufacturing the items cannot raise it's prices out of greed to match the price of an imported item that has had a tariff placed on it.  In the case of China where the government owns the majority of the factories, to tarrif their products is taking money away from their government. They are going to retaliate, putting tarrifs on products grown or manufactured in America, the government loses nothing the farmers and the manufacturers  do. 
Trump can be blamed for his stupidity, but no more than  Bill Clinton for starting "free trade". George Bush put free trade on steroids, followed by Obama who was pushing as hard as he could for even another free trade agreement. The true blame goes all the way back to our old friend Ronald Reagan who cut taxes on large corporations, then was given even more of a boost by the Koch brothers led citizens united. We have allowed corporations to dictate trade policies, tax structure, and banking practices. So you see, Trump may be an extreme idiot, but he is following in the steps of 4 other idiots that held the presidency ahead of him.
